cab.content:
THIS DOCUMENT IS THE PROPERTY OF HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTVS GOVERNMENTPrinted for the War Cabinet. November 1941.SECRET. Copy No.W.M. (41)113th Conclusions.TO BE KEPT UNDER LOCK AND KEY.It is requested that special care may be taken toensure the secrecy of this document.WAR CABINET 113 (41).CONCLUSIONS of a Meeting of the War Cabinet held in the Prime ministers room, House of Commons, S.W. 1, on Thursday, November 13, 1941, at12-30 p.m.Present:The Right Hon. Winston S. Churchill, M.P., Prime Minister (in the Chair).The Right Hon. Sir John Anderson,M.P., Lord President of the Council.The Right Hon. A. Greenwood, M.P.,Minister without Portfolio.The Right Hon. Sir Kingsley Wood,M.P., Chancellor of the Exchequer.The Right Hon. Anthony Eden, M.P.,Secretary of State for ForeignAffairs.The Right Hon. Lord Beaverbrook,Minister of Supply.The Right Hon. Ernest Bevin, M.P.,Minister of Labour and NationalService.The following were also present:The Rt. Hon. H. Dalton, M.P.,Minister of Economic Warfare(Item 1).Sir Edward Bridges, Secretary.Contents.minute no. Subject. Page.1 Blockade .... ............. ............ 150Food Supplies to the Vatican.2 Man-Power ............ .............. 150Employment of Women by Government Departments.Women Labour for Munition Factories.[23152] 1. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs said that a request had been received from the United States: Government thatwe should give facilities for food to be sent to the Vatican. Thepopulation of the Vatican city was about 4,000, and the amountsinvolved were not large. The. Americans cited, in support of this request, the fact that we had allowed a limited amount of food tobe sent into Switzerland, through the blockade.The Foreign Secretary said that he had discussed the matter with the Minister of Economic Warfare, and it was proposed toagree to the request made by the United States Government.In discussion, the view was expressed that the request wasnot altogether easy to justify on merits, nor would it meet withany particular support from public opinion. As, however, therequest was put to us and pressed by the United StatesGovernment, it would be right to accede to it, subject to proper safeguards, making it plain that the request was not one which we found it easy to agree to.The War Cabinet-Accordingly authorised the Foreign Secretary to despatch a telegram (the terms of which had been concerted withthe Minister of Economic Warfare), agreeing to this request.Blockade.Food supplies to the vatican.Man-Power.(PreviousUef erence:W.M. (41) 110thConclusions,Minute 1.)Employmentof Women byGovernmentDepartments.Women labour for munition factories.2. The War Cabinet had a general discussion on certainMan-power questions.In the course of discussion, reference was made to theemployment of women aged 20-30 in clerical posts in GovernmentDepartments.The Minister of Supply said that he was prepared to releaselarge numbers of such women from his Ministry for munition work,provided that similar action was taken by all Departments.The War Cabinet were informed that a difference had arisenon this matter between the Ministry of Labour and the three service departments. A compromise proposal had been put forward by theChancellor of the Exchequer (L.P. (41) 187), which was to beconsidered by the Lord Presidents Committee on the following day.The Prime Minister hoped that no steps would be taken in thismatter which would be to lead to disorganisation of essential workin Government Departments, more particularly in Sections engagedin Confidential duties.The War Cabinet-Took note that this matter was to be discussed at the lord presidents Committee on the following day, and that aReport would be made to the Prime Minister before action was taken.The Minister of Supply said that his great need was to getadditional women workers for munition factories, particularly the filling factories. 37,500 women workers were required for filling factories at once. Absenteeism at the moment represented abouta quarter of the total employed labour. In one factory, Swynnerton,80 per cent, of the intake of labour was lost through wastage.The Minister of Labour and National Service, who said that theMinister of Supply's statement was not in accord with the facts as reported to him, made a statement of the steps which he was taking to obtain women for the munition industries and for the ;auxiliary services.The War Cabinet-Invited the Minister of Supply and the Minister of Labourand National Service to arrange for an agreed statementof the facts to be prepared as to the supply of women workers to the filling factories. This statement should cover in respect of, say, the last two months (a) The outstanding demands for labour.(b) The total number of women (i) supplied to, and(ii) taken on by, these factories.(c) The wastage rate.(d) Absenteeism.Great George Street, S.W.1,November 13, 1941.
so[This telegram is of particular secrecy and should, he retained by the authorised recipient and not passed on],[CYPHER] WAR CABINET DISTRIBUTION.. k/FROM: UNITED STATUS OF AMERICA,, jfFROM WASHINGTON TO FOREIGN 0jig ICE, fViscount Halifax,No, 4-813.22nd October, 19VI.&Foreign Office telegramNo, 3V98 of 19VO,1, Welles told me this afternoon that he had received an intimation from the Vatican, conveyed through the Apostolicdelegate here, of real shortage of essential supplies and of a desire to purchase certain commodities as on the list set out inmy immediately succeeding telegram,Welles said that they could find a ship from maritime commission which would, he thought, sail under the Vatican flagdirect to Naples and carry nothing except the supplies inquestion,2, On the assumption that Mr, Osborne is satisfied thatthere is real need of these supplies, and that they will not"be passed out of Vatican City, Welles felt that it was very desirable to meet the request, as it would be a matter inwhich American Roman Catholics would take great interest^This is obviously true and looked at from here I shouldvery much hope both for this reasons and also because therequest is supported by the United States that you would feel able to grant navicert for the ship in question under conditions to ensure against misuse,3, Please pass to Ministry of Economic Warfare with my immediately following telegram.D. 1,33 p.m.R. 10,5 p,m.&23.rApctober, 19VU2Jrd\october, 1941.individual][Copies sent to II,E. 17, ]
